Subject: Thank you for applying to Fortis Games!
Content:
Dear Seamus,

Thanks for applying to Fortis Games. Your application has been received and we will review it right away.

If your application seems like a good fit for the position we will contact you soon.

Regards,
Fortis Games, Talent Acquisition

Subject: We would like to assess your candidacy further.
Content:
Hi Seamus,

I hope you are doing well=2E =F0=9F=98=8A

My name is Vuk and I will be conducting the recruitment process=2E=C2=A0

Your profile looks very interesting and we would love to get to know you b=
etter! =F0=9F=A5=B3=20

Therefore we are inviting you to the next stage in our process, which cons=
ists of two non-technical online assessments=2E Roboten is a data-driven co=
mpany=2E We use these assessments to ensure that we are able to offer a wor=
kplace and a position in which you can thrive=2E =F0=9F=A6=84=F0=9F=9A=80

The first one is a personality assessment and the other one is a general c=
ognitive ability assessment=2E They tell us a bit about you as a person and=
, more importantly, about your work style=2E They have helped us build grea=
t teams where people complement each other while ensuring that Roboten can =
provide a sufficient work environment=2E In addition, they help us to have =
as fair and unbiased processes as possible=2E We also think they are rather=
 fun, and you will be able to download the results instantly after you comp=
lete them=2E

Some important information regarding the assessments:

I have just sent you a link to these assessments in a separate email, that=
 is sent from a company called Master International A/S using the following=
 address: noreply@master-online=2Ecom=2E Please check your spam folder as t=
he assessments sometimes end up there=2E=20

It is essential that you have a stable internet connection and that you ca=
n conduct the assessments in an environment where you are not being disturb=
ed since they will be sent just once=2E It is not possible to repeat them=
=2E In total, it takes around 1,5 hours to complete both assessments=2E=20

In case you are not able to download the reports, please reach out to us a=
nd we will send them to you=2E =E2=9A=A1=EF=B8=8F

Feel free to reply to this e-mail if you have any questions=2E =F0=9F=99=
=8B=F0=9F=8F=BB=E2=80=8D=E2=99=80=EF=B8=8F

We wish you a lovely day! =E2=98=80=EF=B8=8F

Kind Regards,

Vuk

Roboten

Subject:
Drones of War, Generative AI in the Cloud, K-Pop in Many Tongues,
 Better Weather Forecasts
Content:
Last week, I returned home from Asia, where I spoke at Seoul National Unive=
rsity in Korea, the National University of Singapore, and the University of=
 Tokyo in Japan

View in browser (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwB=
L_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4z5m_5PW8wM7ks6lZ3kKVQmyS07cMnb2W31t9Sf=

X21HwyDVjBF1670fsL2f6cVKwz04 )

Subscribe (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW=
8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3H3l5QzW6N1vHY6lZ3k_N8YQ0TnNVMvRW3vypq57zrNHx=
W5TddbD3gsmttW5yVthm2X9T7NW6YwSq07_Zc7tVZB2C77jn06nW6SnQVq5Py7xLW8DckNm3Sdv=
zTW8v2pb_65Jf7XW12MCSm4dJN3rW5lbkpn2_pNYRW6SwB5_8pN_pKW6CPZyg3h4HgzW7KZt-w3=
QpFHXV_8z_m6N016FN7_DfM3fgXsvW42PRMr8MxkWSW8W-p2b756sbKW9cvrWX2PWk4WW35f5Mw=
7S33qYN3xbjpTd028sW2__jkR1h_bzkf7NYmT004 )    Tips (mailto:thebatch@deeplea=
rning.ai?subject=3DRE%3A%20Tips%20and%20News)

Dear friends,

Last week, I returned home from Asia, where I spoke at Seoul National Unive=
rsity in Korea, the National University of Singapore, and the University of=
 Tokyo in Japan and visited many businesses. As I discussed the state of AI=
 with students, technologists, executives, and government officials, someth=
ing struck me: Around the world, everyone is wrestling with similar AI-rela=
ted issues.

In every country:

- Business leaders are asking how AI will affect their companies.

- Governments are wondering how it will affect the labor market, what risks=
 it poses, and how to regulate it.

- Companies are trying to figure out how to use it without =E2=80=9Cgiving =
away=E2=80=9D their data to one of the platform vendors.

- Developers are experimenting with creative uses of generative AI. The two=
 most common applications remain building customer service chatbots and ans=
wering questions based on documents. But I also heard about numerous creati=
ve projects in medical records, financial records, privacy protection, and =
much more.

When the deep learning revolution started about a decade ago, I advised tea=
ms to (i) learn about the technology, (ii) start small and build projects q=
uickly to hone intuition about what=E2=80=99s possible, and (iii) use learn=
ings from smaller projects to scale to bigger ones. With the generative AI =
revolution, my advice remains the same. This time, though, the barrier to e=
ntry is lower and thus the time-to-value seems to be shorter. It takes subs=
tantial effort to collect data and train and deploy a neural network, but l=
ess effort to prompt a large language model and start getting results.

For developers, this means richer opportunities than ever! Leaders are look=
ing for helpful perspectives. If you=E2=80=99re able to experiment, learn, =
identify successful use cases (and even some failures =E2=80=94 which is fi=
ne, too), and share your insights with colleagues, perhaps you can influenc=
e the trajectory of your business.

Last Friday, I discussed how businesses can plan for generative AI with Eri=
k Brynjolfsson, Andrew McAfee, James Mili, and Daniel Rock, who co-founded =
Workhelix (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW=
8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3H3prCCW6N1vHY6lZ3npW8NwjVr8tpNrKW53Zfnr6ZkhS=
0N9gQwjh8JqlzVD_9qr91PgXXW4Zx5-455gctTW6nhPyy7NZRVBW3GdZjs5XRR-sW99QbcN4D4Y=
G8W1Sl0pl2rK7WxW7_6_xc4BCsRQW733y5m4rHq38W5Vf5vv8mRXrjW91vs0r6gStnmN3YZ4JKK=
Wt8VW6ZvGZ97CZKddW5gJbv-3HBrPSW6vdfmW6k5T7_VYmcCV31-sHxW6HGcdr8xC-rjW6BGjfH=
9cql6lW2r2_255vP1wyVPG5tG1HZcxYf3SH1Ll04 ) (a portfolio company of AI Fund,=
 which I lead). Workhelix helps its customers break down jobs into tasks to=
 see which tasks can be augmented by AI. You can listen to the conversation=
 here (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXb=
w69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3H3prCCW6N1vHY6lZ3pwF5tSZTjFdKtW6gjhHf3CXFrsW2RfF=
S-4YLKJrV-rSbh4KM42MW2ccVRs4ZlP5_W4M_Qhh7q6nqvW6K0nSc7FjN-fW4fTCFF7KM7K-N43=
Rn_wll951W196chR1lzfdwW3drPws2xG6N6VrXBwK7KsrLvW5-pQNR7kS88qW1bymDC54-NcnVP=
LPJR4Qh7g0W2MbB1L4NQtqyW8YzjYT7pT2xbW3Hn_Bx1CWVBrW950f067pw_TyMGRz52JQyZtW1=
_TThb29cNkbW7VjkQP3NfzQHf7z09D604 ) .

For instance, a radiologist=E2=80=99s tasks include (i) capturing images, (=
ii) reading them, (iii) communicating with patients, and so on. Which of th=
ese tasks can take advantage of AI to make a radiologist=E2=80=99s job more=
 productive and enjoyable? Can it help optimize image acquisition (perhaps =
by tuning the X-ray machine controls), speed up interpretation of images, o=
r generate takeaways text for patients?

Although Workhelix is applying this recipe at scale, it=E2=80=99s also usef=
ul for teams that are exploring opportunities in AI. Consider not jobs but =
their component tasks. Are any of them amenable to automation or assistance=
 by AI? This can be a helpful framework for brainstorming interesting proje=
ct ideas.

The way generative AI is taking off in many places around the world means t=
hat our markets are increasingly global. Wherever in the world you live, th=
is is a wonderful time to build your AI knowledge and increase your AI skil=
ls. Exciting opportunities lie ahead!

Special thanks to Ian Park of the Korean Investment Corporation, Chong Yap =
Seng of the National University of Singapore, and Yuji Mano of Mitsui, who =
made my visits much more productive and enjoyable. I also hope to visit oth=
er countries soon. Stay tuned!

Keep learning,

Andrew

P.S. DeepLearning.AI just launched =E2=80=9CEvaluating and Debugging Genera=
tive AI (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8M=
Xbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4z3prCCW8wLKSR6lZ3l4N57ZfNN9C4XXW4G3TNl4D21qlW2=
5XhjL8CkDMYW7lYp1J31vX-1VB-3WG1pqW5VW197dT-3t1K1xW5W9Y9t6W49-sW6W83RD957Q2f=
VQCtcZ15j2vRVDM05p97d-m9W4MBBz-12hHG8W4jzk7P4m25VlW8--j7X86nnpmW79KV3h6zFWt=
ZN8RdwLXn_tDBW4xz1NS3HgY1wW8TN2L_8PNVjjW1GccHP91kHYQW7f8VrD5kNP9MW6fDxyN4q3=
l_ZW7ZgMy759QNFPW1gkjZk4hC5BZW93Yhfg97G8KGW46nQk84RgRkWW7Kvd1k4-mXyzW8MCgfd=
5pCLz0W1G2_fr7PSXFGVgmn2d7T8mg6f1P71ZY04 ) ,=E2=80=9D created in collaborat=
ion with Weights & Biases and taught by Carey Phelps. Machine learning deve=
lopment is an iterative process, and we often have to try many things to bu=
ild a system that works. I used to keep track of all the different models I=
 was training in a text file or spreadsheet. Thankfully better tools are av=
ailable now. This course will teach you how to use them, focusing on genera=
tive AI applications. I hope you enjoy the course!

News

Ukraine=E2=80=99s Homegrown Drones

The war in Ukraine has spurred a new domestic industry.

What=E2=80=99s new: Hundreds of drone companies have sprung up in Ukraine s=
ince Russian forces invaded the country early last year, The Washington Pos=
t reported (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4p=
W8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4z3prCCW8wLKSR6lZ3nsVJPpc45zPhFlW7jdjnr4dQ1b=
KN5VZwB-xPjNRW54lX421CYGdPN4b7R2_hCQC_W82QSlH5slkj8W71KK801wDTKwW2BKJwB8lts=
MBVjfF8V75Kg42W44yfn121GB5RW27yRMh77f6hDW7fPwgZ3ZfxnKN3Pcz897tgg-W3klmmp90F=
HKsW3rkZ9K3npm6BW4B9XxJ8yYc6VN1zJknNzWNbDN2X8VcB673l3W3CYd_Z4_hWCKW7q4ZnW2C=
5Vh0W6CB-c-5S1ClCW2Rt1Bl7DkzPDW2KBmhY1nvHybW9bXkrB1PKS1-W6DdH7l4RJVPYW453fq=
p58TgtKW5jpM_g3C1XncW45lxlZ7JykDDf93GYvH04 ) .

How it works: Ukrainian drone startups are developing air- and sea-borne ro=
bots, which the country=E2=80=99s military use to monitor enemy positions, =
guide artillery strikes, and drop bombs, sometimes on Russian territory.

- Quadcopters built by Twist Robotics use AI-powered target tracking to rem=
ain locked onto targets even if the operator loses radio contact. Air and n=
aval drones from Warbirds have similar capabilities.
- Working in an active war zone gives local drone makers advantages over th=
eir foreign counterparts. For instance, Ukrainian authorities give domestic=
 firms access to captured Russian jamming technology so that they can devel=
op countermeasures. Similarly, the companies acquire huge amounts of real-w=
orld data from the front lines, such as images of tanks or landmines in a v=
ariety of settings, that can be used to train their systems. They also rece=
ive immediate feedback on how their machines perform on the battlefield.
- Foreign companies are angling to get involved =E2=80=94 partly to gain ac=
cess to the same data. Canada-based Draganfly and U.S.-based BRINC are acti=
vely developing drones in Ukraine. German defense-AI company Helsing and U.=
S. data analytics firm Palantir also maintain offices there.

Russia responds: In recent months, Russia has stepped up attacks by Russian=
-made Lancet fliers that explode upon crashing into their targets. Recent u=
nits appear to contain Nvidia Jetson TX2 computers, which could drive AI-po=
wered guidance or targeting, Forbes reported (https://info.deeplearning.ai/=
e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g345m_5PW5B=
Wr2F6lZ3n2W7phhZk4Pk-YfW73wQ9g2GfN7WW1msxBr3JNwmHW1Q6bkX5vWnM7W3rrF4F6s73jP=
N5WxPqQyzdmCW2Yd0gq6nn-ztW97DmgB7ld_H7W2Xkcl94d86YKW2B2mBH35X6mlW9gQcyP6CMJ=
5tW2rXwxy6TSXHCW5kK7gM8XQ6kbW8ybMtk1HymRgN607zjjTqyJxW66K50V6w--f-W5ygkCk2x=
lhbmW2F1lRM3QYHvLW4qqYyK2tn_lXW90fTYG4QfV13W1-qsgD5VPR0FW5fvQRP5ZVkYjW5g5c2=
H7GcNckW3l7jcW6nDVVtW8b24Rd9j74lmVHKrky8zFh3NW3RYP-P519sDyW2zmZCY6ZNMVYMQT5=
MyzC4rJW2gCB6y6qGq6zVmwSGX4wc5kyW3xWg2c9bGhlqW8c8Hjm39TxPvW3tvvP23r2BZvf37C=
tvW04 ) . Russian state news denied that its drones use AI.

Behind the news: Other countries are also gearing up for drone warfare.

- A U.S. Navy group called Task Force 59 recently tested (https://info.deep=
learning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN88=
0g4z3prCCW8wLKSR6lZ3n-W110yPL2W8kDdW6LKBtQ3lrKHHVkktJw6yPg0gW5tTvyj5NRFx_W8=
jQySn4LsV6gW2gRBv87LW7bYW8Ds13N5lmqwpW2jmRdM6rm4dXV6_Fth6H6Sj7W6jRhHj5F2VLX=
W1Z-Vf23wlS3PW5_q64T18jy9WW2fyqG5558HzyN4swJqngC-rRVC8Cmm2wd7WSV5fDqQ6WwhdN=
W8y9wm46jnLc7W7PdN9Z7rvZLZW600HYK1D1cq6Mj_GJ_zxgQQW5Mf3F-8BqJQtW4c6y7W70K1G=
nM9GjCKRpMtyVJ6Hwd4lbtk_W5TTpZ_1_TMLdN5_ykFy4xTzkN9gLhgsJgmsHW5lD6Zn7WJmQTf=
2ZHJWx04 ) a system, built from off-the-shelf components, that identifies t=
hreats based on data from drones, other air vessels, surface ships, and sub=
marines.
- The Israel Defense Forces reportedly deployed (https://info.deeplearning.=
ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4T3prCC=
W95jsWP6lZ3pmW277PhJ52cLYZVTf_RW11nFnnN7YGPvd4LJS6W57H1BH8sZQH1W8bC5tk2RpP8=
LW844lfb8vmC2cW8yM0nc7MjFvNVxZ1Yy5rpq8mW7qmP9S8_5-RVN5sxlsXHCpQ7W36Zzcn2m6K=
ZkW15yrFm2hmF45W48PZgK5fXRMmW3gx4W777rxzLW7gwfmC7sbqXFW8z9_qs5tMgjDW25c1l47=
FTs2yW6SpjzM1V3wf8N24hSTHCHfl5W61HGmx726vPvW3j0l3p2zfS4sW2S08Gp5YCBRgVFWjx1=
6SMVrLW3hwfdv45KcR_W9jWys94yr6hbW1KMn-x8tw-5xW2rZgnn4TCtP0W2Q_SRr401mhSW7M5=
bCq3vHv54W2Ylcm-8Dw6F6f1Y2GM-04 ) an AI system that selects targets for air=
 strikes. A separate system then calculates munition loads, schedules strik=
es, and assigns targets to drones and crewed aircraft.
- Taiwan launched (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjY=
wBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4z3prCCW8wLKSR6lZ3m8W6BHpPv6j1hZvW5dD=
QDW3hSYxNW9cK4ps5p7gk8W81NM8T8B8kcnW1Zq7wh8c8cDRN2SLDvfzTsblW5Vgp7w5QCZv8W1=
DbVQ73VrH2kW4s2J8b28hRydN3yTvdBCY3DYW50HgkV8d1Xb3W7C4rsJ1_lkSmW2Dc3Ds8dG_cQ=
W1cB_5q3xG_cjN1Lp5bxthfMrW1jD6xC6l8W7zW1K-_G37QHd2xW8r4C5j3FYw7WW7JpzjV6Vb3=
NkW1yXWPh9m1r82W8JbFZB7fvG8VW3lcR3Y1_RH9SW5Z5JqN9gbwftW8Mcwbj8f53X1VSBXWm7R=
b8MLW4VZsPb7xpHfjW1bwN0K8hp0bXW38g4Nl1Pvrdnf3KWGc204 ) a major program to b=
uild its own drones.

Why it matters: Drones rapidly have become a battlefield staple, and their =
offensive capabilities are growing. Governments around the world are paying=
 close attention for lessons to be learned =E2=80=94 as are, no doubt, insu=
rgent forces, paramilitary groups, and drug cartels.

We=E2=80=99re thinking: We stand with the brave Ukrainian soldiers as they =
defend their country against an adversary with a much larger air force. War=
 is tragic and ugly. We wish that no one used AI-enabled weapons. But the r=
eality is that peaceful and democratic nations do, if only to defend themse=
lves against adversaries who do the same. We are heartened by recent agreem=
ents (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw=
69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4T3prCCW95jsWP6lZ3pkW3CKlm810hxGcW3WkyDr12Q6qxW3_c=
1xc2lHtP3VN-B6f8y7VPPW6ycSv87tyypMW5pDjr13zqrT1W7TbBRX8LtLCFW41d13b8zGvfwW3=
5q9gb1lBGLvMkVqw0_tZ_kN94zqllz3SWWW6hHf7c1S7bRrN4GxvhxHF7FQW5VbhgP7LB2H_W67=
skSM6T8JvnW7Vs-pv1dqk0VW29gNkt89_z8bW2Z5tFv22xVhyW1MlPbM2G50LkN7cv87wg8plZV=
krRGl2Kwn0jW8x77R05VqdhYW2HXV171dGV-VW1l_X-W1FsT2qW8WpWGq3v__-wW4478jK8Ll25=
-W54X0Z627vcR6W88lnD65fFBfWV-4SPd3Q7WS7W2cb2g52KD9frf1qmBLF04 ) to limit de=
velopment of fully autonomous weapons, and we support the United Nations=E2=
=80=99 proposal (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwB=
L_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3-3prCCW7lCdLW6lZ3psW5rKqjp1WqdslW93LfL=
L3KdZNQVG6ScN3Fkd12W16JBpV8-cFjWW6f-wCV6WSpRjW4N_6Dn4BstcJW93GJb28RfdxhW627=
Ccb3nNZQ0W6bBNHw380Hg_W5R0PqP1lXs3rW6NG_WF4gBT7VW7RLg3c3BmbfRN1JXM52F0DgbW1=
mZrCR1Nyy81MkKfxgvY9nyW3TPCc26ZTm3QW5mDFp94c4Pw-W7XC9Wk4DLbvlW1vC_fl43_hvKW=
7MBvJC4jh_MqW5LlD246QLmjVVgp37b3b_qx7W4X_T4h1jqFKBVnPMh345fMGYf9d111T04 ) t=
o ban them entirely.

Cloud Computing Goes Generative

Amazon aims to make it easier for its cloud computing customers to build ap=
plications that take advantage of generative AI.

What=E2=80=99s new: Amazon Web Services=E2=80=99 Bedrock platform is offeri=
ng (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69=
gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4g5m_5PW7Y9pgv6lZ3ntW4RV8Vb5-6D_FW2Dg0yp50JdkgW1NKrN=
f6pb60DW1n-ypl6R916qW4Z6Y5j1hmXbVW1nRJKC26T0BjW8S94yJ8mTDt1V2z0qp56V_TRN2lQ=
ngZgk9PTW1Zv4Wz3x93q1VbbrZC8cwmjVVGjGfH4nKlTQW4QtyW78Cr6Y8W7Z1mxc6sZyypW27F=

We=E2=80=99re thinking: One challenge to startups that provide an API for g=
enerative AI is that the cost of switching from one API to another is low, =
which makes their businesses less defensible. In contrast, cloud-computing =
platforms offer many APIs, which creates high switching costs. That is, onc=
e you've built an application on a particular cloud platform, migrating to =
another is impractical. This makes cloud computing highly profitable. It al=
so makes offering APIs for generative AI an obvious move for incumbent plat=
forms.

ase, =E2=80=9CMasquerade,=E2=80=9D in English, Japanese, Mandarin, Spanish,=

How it works: Hybe used Neural Analysis and Synthesis (NANSY), a neural spe=
ech processor developed by the Seoul-based startup Supertone, which Hybe ac=
quired in January for $36 million.

- Given a vocal recording, NANSY (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+1=
13/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3H3prCCW6N1vHY6lZ3mHW2=

bFfW_7HKQ-NW38QtC01YRYcRW6V8vkq8H3fr_W3nXDM84RqmK2dPR69204 ) separates pron=
unciation, timbre, pitch, and volume information. It uses wav2vec to analyz=
e pronunciation, a custom convolutional neural network (CNN) for timbre, an=
d a custom algorithm for pitch. To analyze volume, it takes an average acro=
ss a mel spectrogram (a visual representation of a sound=E2=80=99s frequenc=
y components over time). The NANSY recombines the four elements using a CNN=
-based subsystem.
- Lee initially recorded =E2=80=9CMasquerade=E2=80=9D in each of the six la=
nguages. Then the producers recorded native speakers of the non-Korean tong=
ues reading the lyrics in their respective languages. NANSY melded the sung=
 and spoken recordings to adjust Lee=E2=80=99s pronunciation.

rative audio models lately, as fans have used deep learning systems to mimi=
c (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69g=

xHxdK6VCDYKW4hsfJ74KF9J-MLs59rNqS2fW56h6_h496718f7zlf8d04 )  the voices of =
established artists. Reactions from artists and music companies have been m=
ixed.

- The musician Grimes released a tool that allows users to transform their =
own voices into hers. She invited people to try to earn money using her clo=
ned voice in exchange for half of any resulting royalties. More than 300 fa=
ns responded by uploading Grimes-like productions to streaming services.
- Universal Music Group has been less welcoming. The recording-industry gia=
nt demanded that streaming services remove fan-made tracks that feature clo=
ned voices of Universal artists.

Why it matters: This application of generated audio suggests that the techn=
ology could have tremendous commercial value. K-pop artists frequently rele=
ase songs in English and Japanese, and popular musicians have recorded thei=
r songs in multiple languages since at least the 1930s, when Marlene Dietri=
ch recorded her hits in English as well as her native German. This approach=
 could help singers all over the world to reach listeners who may be more r=
eceptive to songs in a familiar language.

We=E2=80=99re thinking: Auto-Tune software began as a tool for correcting f=
laws in vocal performances, but musicians quickly exploited it as an effect=
 in its own right. How long before adventurous artists use pronunciation co=
rrection to, say, sing in their own languages with foreign accents?

Long-Range Weather Forecasts

Machine learning models have predicted (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ct=
c/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4g3prCCW7Y8-PT6l=

vfQSTV4Y_sr3BNd3mW11V-zq4nXzW7W3tSTGX8zD5NYW9bc2HP3tP_CXW6b-CPR4ky_S8W6H8Zq=
f4zB5v2W6drN4k7T56hMW8ml_VW5NJ0GFVxjrlL6G2vPtW4nJpq27xtxl1W6qqmQT3HY4K3W8tw=
qrD18Bv7qVQQ-s24dHzC7W5TfWYV9jQkN4dPnlpb04 ) weather (https://info.deeplear=
ning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4g=
3prCCW7Y8-PT6lZ3njW93NT6y2tXVWCW84-CVy5Zf3MKW3tBcvc92xWyPV4YkJC4PG0MMW8W9-S=
y5RpZHYW7k36vB804r1HW18LGvn40QLxkW6xMnLV6cVCclW7K2Sfw79Hr7vW7vg9QB4MzYv0W2M=
cb7R7ZXYKMVNT22B7gKCKzW1d0ZVy2RR5MrW2ZF9ly3CnTSHW3pGynH5KRZ7RW8d2vB85GVFLsW=
6npVYB5zNbQNW8l6tHh86cvnlW3tqDwL4xCTkNW28_t3k4fLWxtW6yPY936gjp19V2dJJW2nhDL=
gW2PQfgN6bQQQfW8P_7-56PKn88W2wyFRx3gv2hMW8dxsY98B7s0df4NTmmY04 )  a few day=
s ahead of time. A new approach substantially extends the time horizon.

What=E2=80=99s new: Remi Lam and colleagues at Google developed GraphCast (=
https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3=
RW6klx5351NqPJN880g3H3prCCW6N1vHY6lZ3mcW2ndl7t3D44W8W5s0Jbb2jkpcmW8Gs4cm6Wx=
NDhW6GGXrD947-k6VhqLx62YK_X2W4BFYJF6kw-PZW4mF6vC7tGRp0W3HVyn17mfq8yW2dNf7S1=
866nlW867p_L89D1w4W60lQQs3v5YCtW88C1Ms2v9HkbW4rhCmM3qNtsvW3c9f-H6zMfrkW8FvL=
_X7DJBDpVc1vQM95yqP5W67TzmZ25N562W4BBzc28qPlCTVnF7Cc3M1DTDW27vwtF4bM-zDVBFY=
M95QmWJDM9fCXyqWj4wf4xvT_P04 ) , a weather-forecasting system based on grap=
h neural networks (GNNs). Its 10-day forecasts outperformed those of conven=
tional and deep-learning methods.

GNN basics: A GNN processes input in the form of a graph made up of nodes c=
onnected by edges. It uses a vanilla neural network to update the represent=
ation of each node based on those of neighboring nodes. For example, nodes =
can represent customers and products while edges represent purchases, or =
=E2=80=94 as in this work =E2=80=94 nodes can represent local weather while=
 edges represent connections between locations.

Key insight: Short-term changes in the weather in a given location depend o=
n conditions in nearby areas. A graph can reflect these relationships using=
 information drawn from a high-resolution weather map, where each node repr=
esents an area=E2=80=99s weather and edges connect nearby areas. However, l=
onger-term changes in the weather depend on conditions in both nearby and d=
istant areas. To reflect relationships between more distant areas, the grap=
h can draw on a lower-resolution map, which connects areas at greater dista=
nces. Combining edges drawn from higher- and lower-resolution weather maps =
produces a graph that reflects relationships among both nearby and distant =
areas, making it suitable for longer-term predictions.

How it works: GraphCast produced graphs based on high- and low-resolution w=
eather maps and processed them using three GNNs called the encoder, process=
or, and decoder. The authors trained the system on global weather data from=
 1979 to 2017 (https://info.deeplearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_=
T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4g3prCCW7Y8-PT6lZ3pTW8TNpKQ1cHqq7W16MWxS4=
Gdp6CW64M9f31g37hWW1MMy188sydSCW1Bvc2n6tnjC9W1_3tqB1lg7-zV7ZN8f2tLmGKW3WvH0=
M8K_5BcW2lSPq952jSNNW3VTZW03BvhnqW18cSRz8CS4-JW1Nk9r96r3JMcN1v0hb4ZxBgLW5d3=
jvn3nwc4WW5PxQYd33_5CRW2B2N5g3XPpr7W3Lzj2j8vw0ylW3xy6WQ8r5XH-W3gvbQ44tKXPYW=
4Cq1QF5MbNbsW80lLx65Vf1ZrW6l5vng6YBB-1W5NKnPB2yKHKFV8nQrm8BcWR2W47Qvng16_L3=
SW1429hN5h0K5zf8xzm0404 ) . Given a set of weather conditions and a set of =
weather conditions measured 6 hours previously for all locations on Earth, =
GraphCast learned to predict the weather 6 hours in the future and multiple=
s thereof.

- The authors divided a map of Earth into areas 0.25 by 0.25 degrees to mak=
e a graph =E2=80=94 actually a grid =E2=80=94 with roughly 1 million nodes,=
 each containing over 200 values (for conditions such as temperature, humid=
ity, air pressure, wind speed, precipitation, and so on) measured at a give=
n time and 6 hours earlier. The nodes were connected at their northern, sou=
thern, eastern, and western borders.
- The authors created a new graph by connecting each node of the grid to a =
smaller graph of around 41,000 nodes, where each node covered a larger regi=
on and nearby regions were connected via edges. (Specifically, the smaller =
graph=E2=80=99s nodes and edges coincided with those of a sphere divided in=
to roughly 82,000 equilateral triangles. The authors connected nodes in the=
 grid to those in the smaller graph if, when the two graphs were overlaid, =
the distance between them did not exceed a threshold.) Given the smaller gr=
aph, the encoder GNN learned to compute an embedding for each node.
- To produce a multi-resolution graph, the authors represented Earth as an =
icosahedron (12 nodes and 20 equilateral triangles) and iteratively divided=
 each triangle into 4 more triangles. They did this 6 times, creating 6 add=
itional graphs of between 12 and roughly 10,000 nodes. They superimposed th=
ese graphs=E2=80=99 edges over the 41,000-node graph. Given the multi-resol=
ution graph, the processor GNN learned to update the 41,000 node embeddings=
.
- To return the resolution to 0.25 by 0.25 degrees, the authors created yet=
 another graph by connecting the 41,000 nodes to their corresponding locati=
ons among the 1 million nodes on the initial grid. (Specifically, for each =
grid node, they found the triangular face that would contain it if the grid=
 and 41,000-node graph were overlaid. Then they connected the grid node to =
the 3 nodes that formed this triangle.) Given this graph, the decoder GNN l=
earned to compute the change in weather conditions for each node on the gri=
d.
- To predict the next time step, the authors added the decoder=E2=80=99s ou=
tput to the values at the current time step. To forecast further into the f=
uture, they repeated the process, predicting the next time step based on th=
e previously predicted values.
- The system learned to predict the values at the next time step by minimiz=
ing the mean squared error between its predictions and actual measurements =
in 6-hour increments up to three days in advance (that is, over 12 sequenti=
al forecasts).

Results: Using 2018 data, the authors compared GraphCast=E2=80=99s 10-day f=
orecasts to those of a popular European system (https://info.deeplearning.a=
i/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/MWjYwBL_T4pW8MXbw69gtR3RW6klx5351NqPJN880g4g3prCCW=
7Y8-PT6lZ3kFW7Nz9_V40hGS2VgkTmY115DcCW3WhZHn2hZfgpW7WwlWk4chK3qW8d35c_9d_LG=

   =20 =20 La=
st week, I returned home from Asia, where I spoke at Seoul National Univers=
ity in Korea, the National University of Singapore, and the University of T=
okyo in Japan =20 =20
   =20 =20 =20 View in browser =20 =20 =20
     =20 =20
   =20 =20 =09 =20 =20 Subscribe = Tips Dear friends, = Last week, =
I returned home from Asia, where I spoke at Seoul National University in Ko=
rea, the National University of Singapore, and the University of Tokyo in J=
apan and visited many businesses. As I discussed the state of AI with stude=
nts, technologists, executives, and government officials, something struck =
me: Around the world, everyone is wrestling with similar AI-related issues.= In ever=
y country: Business l=
eaders are asking how AI will affect their companies. Government=
s are wondering how it will affect the labor market, what risks it poses, a=
nd how to regulate it. Companies =
are trying to figure out how to use it without =E2=80=9Cgiving away=E2=80=
=9D their data to one of the platform vendors. Developers=
 are experimenting with creative uses of generative AI. The two most common=
 applications remain building customer service chatbots and answering quest=
ions based on documents. But I also heard about numerous creative projects =
in medical records, financial records, privacy protection, and much more.&n=
bsp; When the de=
ep learning revolution started about a decade ago, I advised teams to (i) l=
earn about the technology, (ii) start small and build projects quickly to h=
one intuition about what=E2=80=99s possible, and (iii) use learnings from s=
maller projects to scale to bigger ones. With the generative AI revolution,=
 my advice remains the same. This time, though, the barrier to entry is low=
er and thus the time-to-value seems to be shorter. It takes substantial eff=
ort to collect data and train and deploy a neural network, but less effort =
to prompt a large language model and start getting results. For dev=
elopers, this means richer opportunities than ever! Leaders are looking for=
 helpful perspectives. If you=E2=80=99re able to experiment, learn, identif=
y successful use cases (and even some failures =E2=80=94 which is fine, too=
), and share your insights with colleagues, perhaps you can influence the t=
rajectory of your business. =09 =20 =20 Last Friday, I discussed =
how businesses can plan for generative AI with Erik Brynjolfsson, Andrew Mc=
Afee, James Mili, and Daniel Rock, who co-founded Workhelix (a portf=
olio company of AI Fund, which I lead). Workhelix helps its customers break=
 down jobs into tasks to see which tasks can be augmented by AI. Y =
ou can listen to the conversation here . For instanc=
e, a radiologist=E2=80=99s tasks include (i) capturing images, (ii) reading=
 them, (iii) communicating with patients, and so on. Which of these tasks c=
an take advantage of AI to make a radiologist=E2=80=99s job more productive=
 and enjoyable? Can it help optimize image acquisition (perhaps by tuning t=
he X-ray machine controls), speed up interpretation of images, or generate =
takeaways text for patients? Although Wo=
rkhelix is applying this recipe at scale, it=E2=80=99s also useful for team=
s that are exploring opportunities in AI. Consider not jobs but their compo=
nent tasks. Are any of them amenable to automation or assistance by AI? Thi=
s can be a helpful framework for brainstorming interesting project ideas.=
em> The way=
 generative AI is taking off in many places around the world means that our=
 markets are increasingly global. Wherever in the world you live, this is a=
 wonderful time to build your AI knowledge and increase your AI skills. Exc=
iting opportunities lie ahead! Special tha=
nks to Ian Park of the Korean Investment Corporation, Chong Yap Seng of the=
 National University of Singapore, and Yuji Mano of Mitsui, who made my vis=
its much more productive and enjoyable. I also hope to visit other countrie=
s soon. Stay tuned! = Keep learni=
ng, Andrew = P.S. DeepLe=
arning.AI just launched =E2=80=9C Evaluating and Debugging Generativ=
e AI ,=E2=80=9D created in collaboration with Weights & Biases and t=
aught by Carey Phelps. Machine learning development is an iterative process=
, and we often have to try many things to build a system that works. I used=
 to keep track of all the different models I was training in a text file or=
 spreadsheet. Thankfully better tools are available now. T his cour=
se will teach you how to use them, focusing on generative AI applications. =
I hope you enjoy the course! News =09 =20 =20 Ukr=
aine=E2=80=99s Homegrown Drones The war in Ukra=
ine has spurred a new domestic industry. What=E2=80=99s new: Hundreds of drone companies =
have sprung up in Ukraine since Russian forces invaded the country early la=
st year, The Washington Post r=
eported . How it works: Ukrainian drone startups are devel=
oping air- and sea-borne robots, which the country=E2=80=99s military use t=
o monitor enemy positions, guide artillery strikes, and drop bombs, sometim=
es on Russian territory. Quadcopters built by Twist Robot=
ics use AI-powered target tracking to remain locked onto targets even if th=
e operator loses radio contact. Air and naval drones from Warbirds have sim=
ilar capabilities. Working in an active war zone gi=
ves local drone makers advantages over their foreign counterparts. For inst=
ance, Ukrainian authorities give domestic firms access to captured Russian =
jamming technology so that they can develop countermeasures. Similarly, the=
 companies acquire huge amounts of real-world data from the front lines, su=
ch as images of tanks or landmines in a variety of settings, that can be us=
ed to train their systems. They also receive immediate feedback on how thei=
r machines perform on the battlefield. Foreign compani=
es are angling to get involved =E2=80=94 partly to gain access to the =
same data. Canada-based Draganfly and U.S.-based BRINC are actively develop=
ing drones in Ukraine. German defense-AI company Helsing and U.S. data anal=
ytics firm Palantir also maintain offices there. Russia responds: In recent months, Russia has st=
epped up attacks by Russian-made Lancet fliers that explode upon crashing i=
nto their targets. Recent units appear to contain Nvidia Jetson TX2 compute=
rs, which could drive AI-powered guidance or targeting, Forbes reported . Russian state news deni=
ed that its drones use AI. Behind the news: Other countries are also gearin=
g up for drone warfare. A U.S. Navy gro=
up called Task Force 59 recently tested a system, built from off-th=
e-shelf components, that identifies threats based on data from drones, othe=
r air vessels, surface ships, and submarines. The Israel Defense Forces report=
edly deployed an AI system that selects=
 targets for air strikes. A separate system then calculates munition loads,=
 schedules strikes, and assigns targets to drones and crewed aircraft. Taiwan laun=
ched a major program to build its own drones. Why it=
 matters: Drones rapidly have become a battlefield staple, and their=
 offensive capabilities are growing. Governments around the world are payin=
g close attention for lessons to be learned =E2=80=94 as are, no doubt, ins=
urgent forces, paramilitary groups, and drug cartels. We=E2=80=99re thinking: We stand with the brave Uk=
rainian soldiers as they defend their country against an adversary with a m=
uch larger air force. War is tragic and ugly. We wish that no one used AI-e=
nabled weapons. But the reality is that peaceful and democratic nations do,=
 if only to defend themselves against adversaries who do the same. We are h=
eartened by recent agreements to limit =
development of fully autonomous weapons, and we support the United Nations=
=E2=80=99 proposal to ban them entirely.=

   =20 = =09 =20 =20 Cloud Computing Goes Generative=
h1> Amazon aims to =
make it easier for its cloud computing customers to build applications that=
 take advantage of generative AI. What=E2=80=99s new: Amazon Web Services=E2=80=99=
 Bedrock platform is offering new gen=
erative models, software agents that enable customers to interact with thos=
e models, and a service that generates medical records. The new capabilitie=
s are available in what Amazon calls =E2=80=9Cpreview=E2=80=9D and are subj=
ect to change. How it works: Bedrock launched in April with the=
 Stable Diffusion image generator and large language models including AI21=
=E2=80=99s Jurassic-2 and Anthropic=E2=80=99s Claude. The new additions ext=
end the platform in a few directions. Bedrock added t=
wo models from Cohere: a model named Command for summarizing, copywriting, =
and question answering; and one called Embed, which generates embeddings in=
 more than 100 languages. It also upgraded to Anthropic=E2=80=99s Claude 2 =
and added Stability AI=E2=80=99s newly released Stable Diffusion XL 1.0. The Agents = capability enables use=
rs to incorporate these models into applications that understand and fulfil=
l requests and take advantage of private data. For instance, an airline boo=
king website could build an agent that takes into account an individual=E2=
=80=99s travel history, finds suitable flight schedules, and books selected=
 flights. HealthScribe= helps to generate medical notes after a clinical visit. Language model=
s transcribe conversations between patients and medical professionals, iden=
tify speakers, extract medical terminology such as conditions and medicatio=
ns, and generate summaries. The system complies with United States laws tha=
t protect patent information. Behind the news: Amazon=E2=80=99s major rivals i=
n cloud computing have introduced their own generative-AI-as-a-service offe=
rings. Google Cloud Pl=
atform offers access to generative models such as its PaLM large language m=
odel and Imagen image generator via the Vertex AI service. Its Generative A=
I App Builder aims to help users build customized chatbots and search engin=
es. Microsoft Azure offers OpenAI mo=
dels including GPT-4 and DALL=C2=B7E 2. Why it matters: Access to the latest genera=
tive models is likely to be a crucial factor in bringing AI=E2=80=99s benef=
its to all industries. For Amazon, providing those models and tools to buil=
d applications on top of them could help maintain its dominant position in =
the market for cloud computing. We=E2=80=99re thinking: One challenge to startup=
s that provide an API for generative AI is that the cost of switching from =
one API to another is low, which makes their businesses less defensible. In=
 contrast, cloud-computing platforms offer many APIs, which creates high sw=
itching costs. That is, once you've built an application on a particular cl=
oud platform, migrating to another is impractical. This makes cloud computi=
ng highly profitable. It also makes offering APIs for generative AI an obvi=
ous move for incumbent platforms. =20

   =20 = =09 =20 =20 K-Pop Sings in Many Tongues A Korean pop st=
ar recorded a song in six languages, thanks to deep learning. What=E2=80=99s new: Midnatt (better known as Lee=
 Hyun) sang his latest release, =E2=80=9CMasquerade,=E2=80=9D in English, J=
apanese, Mandarin, Spanish, and Vietnamese =E2=80=94 none of which he speak=
s fluently =E2=80=94 as well as his native Korean. The entertainment compan=
y Hybe used a deep learning system to improve his pronunciation, Reuters reported . You can listen to the results here . How it works=
: Hybe used Neural Analysis and Synthesis (NANSY), a neural speech p=
rocessor developed by the Seoul-based startup Supertone, which Hybe acquire=
d in January for $36 million. Given a vocal r=
ecording, NANSY separates pronunciation, timbre, pitch, and volume in=
formation. It uses wav2vec to analyze pronunciation, a custom convolutional=
 neural network (CNN) for timbre, and a custom algorithm for pitch. To anal=
yze volume, it takes an average across a mel spectrogram (a visual represen=
tation of a sound=E2=80=99s frequency components over time). The NANSY reco=
mbines the four elements using a CNN-based subsystem. Lee initially r=
ecorded =E2=80=9CMasquerade=E2=80=9D in each of the six languages. Then the=
 producers recorded native speakers of the non-Korean tongues reading the l=
yrics in their respective languages. NANSY melded the sung and spoken recor=
dings to adjust Lee=E2=80=99s pronunciation. Behind the news: The music industry has been pay=
ing close attention to generative audio models lately, as fans have used de=
ep learning systems to mimic the v=
oices of established artists. Reactions from artists and music companies ha=
ve been mixed. The musician Gr=
imes released a tool that allows users to transform their own voices into h=
ers. She invited people to try to earn money using her cloned voice in exch=
ange for half of any resulting royalties. More than 300 fans responded by u=
ploading Grimes-like productions to streaming services. Universal Music=
 Group has been less welcoming. The recording-industry giant demanded =
that streaming services remove fan-made tracks that feature cloned voices o=
f Universal artists. Why it =
matters: This application of generated audio suggests that the techn=
ology could have tremendous commercial value. K-pop artists frequently rele=
ase songs in English and Japanese, and popular musicians have recorded thei=
r songs in multiple languages since at least the 1930s, when Marlene Dietri=
ch recorded her hits in English as well as her native German. This approach=
 could help singers all over the world to reach listeners who may be more r=
eceptive to songs in a familiar language. We=E2=80=99re thinking: Auto-Tune software began as a tool for =
correcting flaws in vocal performances, but musicians quickly exploited it =
as an effect in its own right. How long before adventurous artists use pron=
unciation correction to, say, sing in their own languages with foreign acce=
nts? =20

   =20 =20
   =20 = =09 =20 =20 Long-Range Weather Forecasts Machine learnin=
g models have predict=
ed weather &nb=
sp;a few days ahead of time. A new approach substantially extends the time =
horizon. What=E2=80=99s new: Remi Lam and colleagues at G=
oogle developed GraphCast , a weather-forecasting system based on graph=
 neural networks (GNNs). Its 10-day forecasts outperformed those of convent=
ional and deep-learning methods. GNN basics: A GNN processes input in the form of=
 a graph made up of nodes connected by edges. It uses a vanilla neural netw=
ork to update the representation of each node based on those of neighboring=
 nodes. For example, nodes can represent customers and products while edges=
 represent purchases, or =E2=80=94 as in this work =E2=80=94 nodes can repr=
esent local weather while edges represent connections between locations. Key insight: Short-term changes in the weather i=
n a given location depend on conditions in nearby areas. A graph can reflec=
t these relationships using information drawn from a high-resolution weathe=
r map, where each node represents an area=E2=80=99s weather and edges conne=
ct nearby areas. However, longer-term changes in the weather depend on cond=
itions in both nearby and distant areas. To reflect relationships between m=
ore distant areas, the graph can draw on a lower-resolution map, which conn=
ects areas at greater distances. Combining edges drawn from higher- and low=
er-resolution weather maps produces a graph that reflects relationships amo=
ng both nearby and distant areas, making it suitable for longer-term predic=
tions. How it works: GraphCast produced graphs based on=
 high- and low-resolution weather maps and processed them using three GNNs =
called the encoder, processor, and decoder. The authors trained the system =
on global weather dat=
a from 1979 to 2017 . Given a set of weather conditions and a set of wea=
ther conditions measured 6 hours previously for all locations on Earth, Gra=
phCast learned to predict the weather 6 hours in the future and multiples t=
hereof. The authors div=
ided a map of Earth into areas 0.25 by 0.25 degrees to make a graph =E2=80=
=94 actually a grid =E2=80=94 with roughly 1 million nodes, each containing=
 over 200 values (for conditions such as temperature, humidity, air pressur=
e, wind speed, precipitation, and so on) measured at a given time and 6 hou=
rs earlier. The nodes were connected at their northern, southern, eastern, =
and western borders. The authors cre=
ated a new graph by connecting each node of the grid to a smaller graph of =
around 41,000 nodes, where each node covered a larger region and nearby reg=
ions were connected via edges. (Specifically, the smaller graph=E2=80=99s n=
odes and edges coincided with those of a sphere divided into roughly 82,000=
 equilateral triangles. The authors connected nodes in the grid to those in=
 the smaller graph if, when the two graphs were overlaid, the distance betw=
een them did not exceed a threshold.) Given the smaller graph, the encoder =
GNN learned to compute an embedding for each node. To produce a mu=
lti-resolution graph, the authors represented Earth as an icosahedron (12 n=
odes and 20 equilateral triangles) and iteratively divided each triangle in=
to 4 more triangles. They did this 6 times, creating 6 additional graphs of=
 between 12 and roughly 10,000 nodes. They superimposed these graphs=E2=80=
=99 edges over the 41,000-node graph. Given the multi-resolution graph, the=
 processor GNN learned to update the 41,000 node embeddings. To return the r=
esolution to 0.25 by 0.25 degrees, the authors created yet another graph by=
 connecting the 41,000 nodes to their corresponding locations among the 1 m=
illion nodes on the initial grid. (Specifically, for each grid node, they f=
ound the triangular face that would contain it if the grid and 41,000-node =
graph were overlaid. Then they connected the grid node to the 3 nodes that =
formed this triangle.) Given this graph, the decoder GNN learned to compute=
 the change in weather conditions for each node on the grid. To predict the =
next time step, the authors added the decoder=E2=80=99s output to the value=
s at the current time step. To forecast further into the future, they repea=
ted the process, predicting the next time step based on the previously pred=
icted values. The system lear=
ned to predict the values at the next time step by minimizing the mean squa=
red error between its predictions and actual measurements in 6-hour increme=
nts up to three days in advance (that is, over 12 sequential forecasts). Results: Using 2018 data, the authors compared G=
raphCast=E2=80=99s 10-day forecasts to those of a popular European system that predicts weath=
er based on differential equations that describe atmospheric physics. Compa=
red to actual measurements, GraphCast achieved a lower root mean squared er=
ror in 90 percent of predictions. It produced a 10-day forecast at 0.25-deg=
ree resolution in under 60 seconds using a single TPU v4 chip, while the Eu=
ropean system, which forecasts at 0.1-degree resolution, needed 150 to =
240 hours on a supercomputer. GraphCast also outperformed Pangu-Weather=
, a transformer-based method, in 99.2 percent of predictions. Yes, but: GraphCast=E2=80=99s predictions tended=
 to be closer to average weather conditions, and it performed worse when th=
e weather included extreme temperatures or storms. Why it matters: Given a graph that combines mult=
iple spatial resolutions, GNN can compute the influence of weather over lar=
ge distances using relatively little memory and computation. This sort of g=
raph structure may benefit other applications that process large inputs suc=
h as ultra-high resolution photos, fluid dynamics, and cosmological data.=
p> We=E2=80=99re thinking: When it comes to forecas=
ting weather, it looks like deep learning is the raining champ. =20

t disruption is your ability to take advantage of innovation. That=E2=80=99=
s why enabling employees to learn rapidly is a business imperative. Read Kian Katanforoosh's =
essential guide to learning velocity for business . =20

Howdy Danny, I'm in Wexford Ireland so my timezone is gmt+1, same as=20
London, and I'm available starting September 1st for 40hrs a week full=20
time.=20

You can see a playable example of my work in the Lego Duplo Marvel=20
<https://storytoys.com/apps/lego-duplo-marvel/> mobile app, there is a free=
=20
playpack you get when you download the app. I worked on the product from=20
its inception, on all aspects of the game but particularly on purchasing,=
=20
architecture, UI, and core systems that support gameplay. I did also do a=
=20
fair amount of work on gameplay but that was primarily the remit of the=20
junior engineers on my team. As well as leading the engineering I drove a=
=20
significant portion of the design direction, I have previously worked in=20
both game design and as a creative technologist for Fjord the design=20
studio, so this was not unusual for me. And I also paid special attention=
=20
to our deliverables, deadlines, client expectations, and managing the flow=
=20
of our work on Jira and Miro.=20

I also lead these two projects for the Virtual Wild

Subject:
[Upcoming Event] Deep dive into LLM Evaluation with Weights &
 Biases
Content:
Join our workshop with Weights & Biases to evaluate LLM systems, focusing o=
n Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.

Dear Friends,

Join us in our next webinar, where we will dive into how we can effectively=
 evaluate Large Language Models (LLMs) systems, with a particular focus on =
Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.

We'll start by discussing the 'eye-balling' technique and why Weight & Bias=
es Prompts stands out as the first great tool in this area. Then, we'll mov=
e on to supervised evaluation, highlighting why it's worth considering and =
pointing out some limitations. To wrap things up, we'll look at how LLMs ca=
n be used to evaluate themselves - from generating their own evaluation dat=
asets, to using standard metrics like SQuAD or BLUE, and even evaluating re=
trieval systems.

This workshop is based off the foundational learnings of DeepLearning.AI=E2=
=80=99s course on Evaluating and Debugging Generative AI  (https://info.dee=
plearning.ai/e3t/Ctc/LX+113/cJhC404/VWZVX71tDjK2N7tNT-mFptV-W7FnbcL51N8G2N5=
